description:
Came here while waiting for a family member having some surgery done at CPMC. Wasn't sure what to get so got my usual of sticky rice.

The sticky was was much cheaper than my usual place of Good Mong, being only $1.50 each. The taste was not bad but rice was bit hard.
author: M C.

description: Came at 11:45am on a Tuesday and half their menu was crossed off. I ordered pork siu mai, beef rice noodle roll, and steamed taro cake. The pork siu mai and beef rice noodle roll were both extremely fatty, it was not a pleasant experience eating marinated chewy pieces of fat. The rice noodle roll was 90% rice noodle and 10% fatty meat.
author: Lillian T.

description:
Came for a quick meal with grandma who has the connections at this location. We were able to get 2 piping hot bowls of wonton noodle soup and an order of steamed rice noodles for $9 - wow! 

The rice noodles were thick but still had a nice supple texture albeit being on the oily side. It was speckled nicely with dried shrimp and green onions though so there was good flavor on every bite! Wish it came with some sweet soy sauce or chili oil though - can't be picky at a cafeteria style dim sum joint though.

As for the wonton noodle soup, the noodles were cooked just right in a delicious chicken broth. They also included probably 8 wontons or more which I considered a great value despite the fact that they don't use shrimp in their version. 

All in all, good meal. The tables could definitely use a good wipedown though.
author: Elaine Y.

description:
My parents were coming over to help me move apartments. Being my parents, they brought me food! (My parents love feeding me.) They arrived with lunch for the four of us (the fourth being the roommate) on Sunday, July 16th around 12pm.

*Deep Fried Meat Dumpling (Ham Sui Gok)
*Har Gow (Shrimp)
*Pork Sui Mi
*Beef Sui Mi
*Sweet Rice with Chicken in Lotus Leaf (Lo Mai Gai)
*Vegetable Chow Mein

Based on the pictures of the menus on Yelp, I believe we got everything above. The ha gow and both shu mai were good. The shao mais were nice and meaty. The ha gow had a good amount of shrimp and the wrapper was the right consistency. I haven't had a ham sui gok in forever, but this one didn't have much filling. I also thought the outside was too thick. It was nice and crispy though. The lo mai gai was also just all right. Not much filling in this either. I thought the chow mein was awful! No flavor at all. Though I'm not a huge veggie noodle person. I need my meat!

Good dim sum basics, but I didn't really like anything else. I'd only come back for the ha gow and siu mai.
author: Elena N.

description:
It's okay. Maybe 3 1/2 stars. We like our spot in Chinatown  more so in that it's less money and the dim sum is bigger

There was a line so we feel that's a good sign and got in it. Only one person waiting on people and taking the money. It was very slow that's why I dinged a star

Steamed pork bun
Pork shrimp scallops dumplings 
Seasame ball

This is a fun street to eat, go to  Chinese or Korean grocery stores and shop,at goodwill
author: Foodlover B.

description: Best spring egg rolls in the city!!! Deep fried meat dumpling & shrimp and chive was delicious too! Head a few doors down to Clement BBQ to get your potsticker fix on. Yummy!! Will def be back!
author: Kylie F.

description:
I almost never leave a bad review, but I just think it's a good heads up for anyone looking for dim sum. I came here Sunday afternoon after realizing that my favorite dim sum spot (Goodluck Dim Sum). My boyfriend and I ordered chive dumplings, chive and shrimp dumplings, BBQ pork bun, sweet egg yolk bun, and 2 orders of pork and shrimp siu mai. 

Heads up: bit into the siu mai and it wasn't cooked at all inside. The outside looked perfectly fine and my boyfriend simply thought it was fatty inside, but as someone who grew up with dim sum, I already knew it didn't taste right. Spit it out and it was red, raw meat. *barf*. 

Everything else was fine I guess (we were both extremely hungry and just wanted food). Mediocre dim sum but the siu mai turned me off so much that I simply can't recommended and wouldn't go back. 

Note: wanted to try their xiao long bao but they didn't have any.
author: Penny C.

description: I have been coming here for years. It is the best dim sum bakery in The City. (Well, Good Mong Kok is better, but this is on Clement and has a much much shorter line.) Their prices have doubled in recent years, but what hasn't in San Francisco? Still it is the best tasting food for the money you can get. The pork siu mai may actually be the best single bite of food at any price. The fon gor and har gow is good too. So superior to the Good Luck Dim Sum across the street. Worth a detour.
author: Bryan F.

description:
I come here for their dimsum, their noodle roll... is so soft and delicious. Since I live in the peninsula, every chance I get, I would come here and get that roll. Although it has dried shrimp, but it has green onions and that dehydrated daikon which makes the roll crunchy. They hand pull their noodles that's why it's so soft. 

Their prices aren't bad, especially their needle noodles... it's 2.00 for a small and 3.00 for a large... one dollar more for a large... and it's pretty big. Lunch can be for 2... think about it, $1.50 per person! It isn't oily at all!!!

They do have stuff like fun gor, siew mai, ha gow, and pork buns, lo bak go, etc. There's a seating area for people who wants to eat inside. There's coffee and a restroom.

I would recommend this place for people who want a quick fix of dim sum... yum!
author: Eugenia W.

description:
A solid place to pick up dim sum as well as various foods by the pound, my mom loves to buy their chow mein, which you can then take home and add whatever you want to it like meats or vegetables, and it reheats perfectly for future meals.

The pricing is really fair and reasonable here.  The service is with a smile and very gracious.

The only thing I'd say is watch out for some of the patrons, mainly the old Chinese ladies as they'll bum rush the stage wanting to get to the front of the counter to place their order without much concern for process, procedure and etiquette, cutting in front, using their sharp boney elbows and ending up in front of you. 

Parking in the area can be tough since this is located at the heart of Richmond District's Clement Street shopping area.
author: Rick S.

description: Wouldn't give it many more stars because of how we were treated for takeout. Said there was no rice(?!?!?) (how could an asian place not have rice) no soup except "porridge " despite soups on the menu. Only allowed 2pckets of soy sauce. Otherwise dim sum good not great have had way better in the city.
author: Catherine F.

description:
The asian lady at the counter, her name is pronounced "Kaan" or "Keen" depending on what dialect of chinese that you speak. Super helpful. Probably because I had someone to help me interpret & converse. 

We ordered over $100 of dim sum, and called ahead to order. Usual selections purchased include: har gow, beef siu mai, steamed pork buns, steamed chicken buns, & taro root dumplings.

For 3 pieces, it's only $1.80. Extremely reasonable pricing. Highly recommended. Make sure you bring someone who speaks Cantonese to conquer the language barrier.
author: Melissa J.

description: This review is only for their ha gows. They're the best! The dumpling is fat with the shrimp and the flavor is just right. I've had other ha gows in Chinatown but this one takes my top spot. Recently I ordered two dozen to go and shared with my family, who enjoyed them as well. There's always a line whenever I go but it doesn't take too long.
author: Cameron G.

description:
This was my third stop on my Richmond dim sum search.

*Note* I am basing all of my dim sum reviews on the following three items (as they are my favorites): Baked bbq pork bun, Har gao and Siu Mai.

Bao - They were sold out of this. I'll have to try this some other time.

Har gao - This was the best har gao I've had so far in SF. The damn thing was so moist it was practically falling apart. The outside was thin but still tasty. The inside had not only lots of shrimp, but also included something that gave it great flavor. I think it may have been ginger? or egg? I don't know but it was delicious.

Siu mai - I really liked their siu mai as well. While it didn't blow me away as much as the har gao did, it was also really flavorful and moist. It was also a little fatty on the inside, which I enjoyed.

-

I'm not sure why, but there was no plasticware or napkins provided, nor were there any in the shop. So this one had to be eaten by hand, which I am perfectly ok with.

This was definitely the best find on today's dim sum search on clement street. I would come back here again.
author: Mark O.

description: This review is only for their dim sum. Hidden gem as I like the skin (wrapping) of my various dim sum (i.e. Har Gow, Siu Mai) to be thin to the point that the ingredients are almost translucent in the wrapping. I have gone countless times with their products that I buy being consistent.
author: Richard H.

description:
Back in the day when I was growing up, there used to be a King Norman's here...
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/CgrDoK7B3fXp0Og5eAd30Q?select=teCn5zmwD8_4nhTtf1bGbg#oWC3WfcC1xLWLCMz1LvMuw

But now, on xmas morning, they are a life saver as far as getting any Deep Fried Meat Dumplings (hom sui gok) are concerned http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/CgrDoK7B3fXp0Og5eAd30Q?select=teCn5zmwD8_4nhTtf1bGbg#teCn5zmwD8_4nhTtf1bGbg.  Good luck finding any at Good Luck, and there were none to be had at Clement on Clement.  So next one up is Gourmet Dim Sum and Cafe.  Oh we're in luck, the Asian horde hasn't gotten to them all...

We completed our quest of buying dim sum to bring over to my bro-in-laws house on xmas morning and this was our last stop and savior...
author: Lawrence L.

description:
Rude service!
They didn't have enough food&dim sum for customers!
The poor experience cause us very angry!
And their food are all heated by microwave ,but their microwave is out of control,they ask us eat cold food!!!!
Beside,the restaurant is super dirty,I saw a big mouse when I ate!!!
I think that the experience is the worst !!!!!!!
態度不好、食物都用微波的 收了錢後就說微波爐故障，強迫我們吃冷的食物，是個非常差的經驗！（餐廳內還有大老鼠）
author: Karen T.

description:
Fresh made pork dumpling is my favorite
Chow mein is delicious when it's hot and remember to add some hot sauce too
author: Phyllis C.

description:
While doing some early morning wandering around the Richmond Chinese neighborhood, I was on a particular mood to try a hole-in-the-wall shop serving dim sum and breakfast foods from the counter, with a certain type of clientele (older folks settled in with newspapers).  I suppose I could have researched this ahead of time, but I went with the random-looking-in method and deciding on vibe.  So I ended up at the deceptively (but oh-so Chinese) named Gourmet Dim Sum and Cafe.

As desired, its a tiny place with just two rows of 2-seat tables and a counter selling the goods, above which hung the plain, large menu in Chinese and English.  Being illiterate in Chinese, I went with just asking for shrimp rice rolls and siu mai, which were promptly microwaved for me.  The unusual part of this experience were the rice rolls, which had a bizarrely spongy consistency.   The shrimps were tiny and a bit fishy tasting.  The siu mai were nothing special, nothing unusual, solidly mediocre.  Glad I only tried this much and beat a hasty retreat, this cafe's appeal lost on me.
author: Valery C.

description:
Super hit or miss. Delicious or whatever the name is across the street was closed. There was a decent-sized queue of local Canto folk lined up here, but I soon learned.. very very hit or miss. 

More than likely, what you're gonna want you will have to take a seat and wait for it to be steamed or cooked up. 

Not much offering around 11AM yesterday. things like steamed pork buns, or siu mai were not available. Out. Not liking the wait time in line to the actual availability of dim sum items. 

Pass, thanks. Must add, in closing, that their sesame balls were very well done and fluffy, crispy ratio well done. The hot dog bun I got to eat at work was the hugest thing i have ever seen. A giant bread that was tasty enveloping some kind of cheap weiner. 

Choice of words there.... for comic effect =0
author: Jana C.

description:
One of my Clement go-to's. They're fast and the dim sum is decent enough. 
They don't have a huge variety, but what do you expect? This isn't a sit down restaurant.
They mostly have dumplings, but they also have a couple of baos 
3 dumplings for $1.50, CHEAP.

On my last visit, I picked up

6 har gow (not for me since I'm allergic to shrimp)
3 siu mai
1 lo mai gai
1 preserved egg pork porridge

ALL FOR $7! 

i was full, but did have minor MSG after effects :[  


Sometimes, you cannot have your cake and eat it too. 

Still it's fast, cheap, decent.
author: Susy C.

description: Terrible food and service. Food is really bad. Hot coffee is not hot. Dim sum is not fresh. The place is very dirty. Won't go there anymore.
author: Kato K.

description:
Who doesn't love cheap giant dim sum To Go?  I got the Shrimp leek dumpling, Har Gow, Siu Mai, Pork and Century Egg Porridge, and Lo Bak Go.  Just reheat the stuff when you take it home.  Overall, they have the key staples for Dim Sum and you won't break the bank like you would normally at a restaurant.

Cash only!
author: Viva C.

description:
I was on a weekend getaway with my girlfriends to San Francisco!! I haven't been in a few years so I was pretty excited. My mission: GET SOME GOOD DIM SUM!! 

Turns out my mission was a fail. 

The good:
It's in San Francisco? And that's such a great city. 
The dim sum, most everything was just $1.50
I got so much food to fill my tummy and then some for just over $6! 
They had a few tables to sit and eat at the restaurant. 

The bad:
The food was not so good, I've had better in LA.
I thought to myself, if I get the runs on this trip I'm blaming you Gourmet Dim Sum and Cafe!! 
Some of items that ordered they warmed up in the microwave and served it to me. No bueno.
The tables were dirty, we had to clean them off ourselves and when my friend asked a question about the table the lady was really rude and said something to her in Chinese. My friend is Japanese so we had a little communication trouble.

I will not be returning here. I think I can do much better while I'm in SF.
author: Lily A.

description: I stopped coming here for a while. These people started to have an attitude awards me for no apparent reason. i usually buy a lot of dim sum here here every time I come here and was my favorite place.  Might not ever come back here to buy dim sum again. Their are a lot of other places in Clement where I can buy Dim Sum. Good Luck Dim Sum have some nice dim sum. On my way there. only a block away.
author: Peter N.

description:
4 stars for the food, 5 stars for bang for yer buck

Awesome, this place is a little shop right by 7th and Clement. I've walked by it a couple of times now in favour for Good Luck dim sum which happens to be just a street down, but honestly this place is just as solid as Good Luck dim sum, with a little less variety. If you are looking for the go-to dimsum selection (siu mai, crystal (filling) dumplings, BBQ (pork|chicken) buns) then this place won't let you down. It doesn't have much seating space so don't go in expecting a seat. 

The bottom line is that this place serves damn good dim sum, and comes short just about every where else. If you are looking for no frills dim sum then this place is a solid option.
author: David C.

description: Their har gaw and chives har gaw is consistently delicious - crispy, cooked perfectly, and flavorful.   The service is attentive by answering my many questions.  This is one of the best place for dim sum to go with less of the pretentious crowd who wants a 5 star experience at 1 dollar sign prices.
author: Anna C.

description: Yummmm. I love dim sum. Prices here are pretty reasonable, and dim sum - well how can you really go wrong with dim sum? Don't answer that - I don't want to know. They're fast and the selection is pretty large. Oh, and their chow mein is really good here - the small container is hefty! Not my favorite dim sum place ever, but when I'm in the area & craving dim sum, I definitely don't mind stopping by for a bite. Or two. Or you know. A food coma.
author: Amy L.

description:
My ultimate dim sum place on Clement. This place has food for cheap and theyir items are delicious. This would have to be my go to place for pork siu mai and their rice noodles. Chow mein here is always the best place for it where the PACK your entire box to the brim. This place has everything from dim sum to noodle soups to porridge and baos. 

However, if you are in a rush sometimes it does get extremely packed and typically it is only one lady packing everyones orders and she is fast, nice and friendly but only one lady can do so much.
author: Angela S.

description:
I was in the Bay area visiting family and this was the last stop with my Bay area family. We had eaten less than four hours ago, but like I stated in a previous review, nothing brings a good time like gathering together with lots of good eats.

Because we were not that hungry, I thought we could Food Truck it and try different tastes with the family. Via Twitter, we could not find a Food Truck close to our location....BUMMER....so we decided to eat here at the Gourmet Dim Sum and Cafe.

It was around 2:00PM on Sunday when we found this place and we probably missed the lunch crowd after church services. That was good...we had the restaurant to ourselves.

The restaurant ran out of some of out favorite dim sum items, but they prepared some for us quickly....that's good!

Excuse my spelling....I just eat Dim Sum. We ordered lots of shumai, shrimp and chive dumplings, meat pie bau, and sesame balls. (see my iPhone pictures)

Honestly, this was filler food. With soy sauce and rooster sauce saved some of the tastes of the food.

The good was that this place was extremely inexpensive and the person behind the counter made us more food.

But with all the good, the lack of taste can only get a Two and a Half Yelp Star rating from me....round up to Three Yelp Stars for ya!  =)
author: Albert E.

description:
My excursion to the Clement corridor continues with a visit to Gourmet Dim Sum and Cafe. This is another fast food dim sum place that has a small seating area to the side. Lighting and layout are not the best but it does have three huge multi-deck steamers where all the goodies are nicely tucked underneath. The long listing of dim sum items are posted behind the counter and most can be had at $1.50 for three.

I swooped in and got the following items for a huge $4.50 feast. It was enough to get me full but I always make room for dessert.

Shrimp dumplings--Fresh, juicy and plump with good texture and taste.
Scallop dumplings--Better than the ones at Good Luck Dim Sum.
Chive dumplings--Very good with ground pork and plenty of chives.
Sweet rice buns--Sticky rice is one of my favorites at all dim sum places--a must get.
Turnip cake--It was reheated with microwave but still decent.

I felt my meal was somehow incomplete when I found out that they had already ran out of taro dumplings. I also wish that they could turn up the steamer so food could be served at a higher temperature. Service was straight forward and accessible. 

All in all, this place is pretty good and a nice alternative when Good Luck gets too crowded. I'm celebrating another decent find with hip-hop artist Jin's Cantonese Youtube video about dim sum. Please pardon the problematic images but this might still be a helpful tool for those who have been asking me for a crash intro to dim sum 101.

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=i7nT0t5hKHI&feature=related

3.5 stars for above average Chinese fast food.
author: Daniel L.

description:
Continuing my reviews of shops on the Clement corridor, my next stop was Gourmet Dim Sum and Cafe. The owner/chef trained in upscale gourmet places so he decided to name his own place as such. Although the "scrungy" interior doesn't reflect that name.

This is one of many underrated dim sum places on Clement street. Perhaps because they're located just one block from the ever popular Good Luck Dim Sum (GLDS). The only break they get is on Tuesdays when GLDS is closed. They get extra points because service is a lot nicer here than at GLDS, by far.

It's not the best dim sum I've ever had, but I like the overall value you get. Most items are priced at 3 for $1.50 (menu items #1-23), except for the following popular items:
- egg custard (#25) for 60 cents
- baked BBQ pork bun (#26) for 75 cents - very nice plump buns!
- chow mein (#36) at $1.50 (small) / $2.50 (large), it's a vegetarian version, mostly noodles with a few strands of carrots and sprouts (I prefer to go to Wei Lee for chow mein).

So, what makes this place a standout favorite for many regular customers? obviously the low price comes first, fairly good decent quality, seating space to read your newspaper, and two popular menu items:
- #28 - pork or chicken porridge (aka. congee or jook) for $2. It's just a very basic rice soup, but the pricing is phenomenal.
- #33 - wonton soup for $3 ($3.50 with noodles), the quality is surprisingly decent considering the rock bottom price, and they don't skimp on the number of wontons either. It's a fantastic deal for most senior residents on a fixed income, and budget-minded customers.

My rating is 3.5 stars rounded up to 4 stars. Note that my criteria for full service sit down restaurants is different, so don't try to compare those ratings to hole-in-the-wall places like this one.

CASH only.
author: Luis C.

description: Tasty food and great service.  It is not fancy but it tastes authentic and the prices are more than fair.  Great for lunch or a quick bite when you are in a hurry.  I will be going back soon!
author: Andrew B.

description:
I tried three types of the dumplings at this restaurant recently.  I had the plain shrimp, the shrimp and chive and the scallop which is actually more shrimp than scallop.  

All three dumplings had the nice thin, chewy, translucent skin on them.  The shrimp dumpling had firm shrimp and bits of bamboo, but I tasted a bit of an MSG kick after eating them.  You'd know it because MSG leaves a residue on your tongue and makes you thirsty for hours to follow.  I didn't get the MSG after effects on the other two selections however.  The shrimp and chive dumpling had chopped up green chives, bamboo bits and firm shrimp.  The scallop dumpling had lots of firm shrimp, but only fine slivers of scallops, finely chopped carrot, bamboo and chives.

Service was very good, but a current health department rating of only 82 might make you decide to take your dumplings to go instead.  The dumplings are priced at $1.50 for 3.  They're tasty but not the best I've had.
author: Wilhelm Y.

description:
My to go order consisted of one chive dumpling, two shrimp sui mai and a dragon boat tamale.  The dumpling and sui mai were very good and fresh tasting.  I ate the lo mai gow a few hours later and I got an awful MSG headache and feel just plain crappy.  

I should've stuck with the original plan and gone someplace else instead.

Excuse me while I drink another gallon of water.
author: .Hon H.

description:
This review is based on their chow mein & service alone.

I give their chow mein 3 stars for taste. It's decent, and vegetarian, and I like the crunchy bean sprouts in it.

I give it's price & portion size 5 stars. $1.50 for a small plastic container STUFFED full. It's like a clown car, you'll be amazed how much they can fit in there. If you can actually finish it, next time pay $2.50 for the large, which is really more like 3 times more than the small.

I give 1 star for the fact the woman serves your food, then takes your money, gives you change, and serves the next person, all while never washing her hands or taking gloves on & off.

Guess that evens to 3 stars.
author: Venus S.

description: Their chow mein and spare ribs taste better than Good Luck Dim Sum's because they are not as oily and they don't use starch. The siu mai is not as good as Good Luck's  because sometimes I find some parts too chewy to swallow.
author: Robert S.

description:
3.5 stars

We tried 3 different dim sum places on Clement.  We got one piece each of some kind of dumplings.  Here, we got shrimp dumpling - very good with the right skin and plenty shrimp. Parsley shrimp dumpling - again, quite good.  Lastly the scallop dumpling - not bad.  

Most places are 3/$1.50 so you can buy a piece at $0.50 or mix as you wish to try as much variety until you find your favorite ones.
author: Gloria H.

description:
Tasty,
Fast
Dim sum. These people are my friends because they feed me.
author: Ally Y.

description: It's no Good Luck Dim Sum, but there's no line and we didn't want to wait. Their Har Gow is actually as good or better than GLDS but everything else is a pale comparison.
author: Henry Y.

description:
I've experienced some bad news.

So usually, when I'm in a bad mood, most of the men in my life stay away except for a few here and there who know how to pat down my puffy hair that is singed with the amount of electrostatic running through the roots.  What makes me happy, is that I've found a cute little place that is not only successful in bringing little sparks of joy to my eyes BUT offers excellent customer service. So so lacking in another place I'm going to review after this place.

Gourmet Dim Sum is located directly next to a market on a busy corner of Clement so when the fellow who is alert to my catfish whiskers lengthening horizontally went to the market, I slipped into the Dim Sum shop to experience what they might have for this angry little Asian.

There was no one behind the counter, but the minute the sitting clients in the back saw me, they mentioned something in Chinese to the back kitchen and this little old lady walks out.  She preps herself in front of me with her hands and napkins and says "yes?"

I ordered the last ten steamed pork buns and two egg custard buns.  This came out to $5 even.  Holy shit.  That inexpensive.  I proceeded to sit down and ease my impending hunger with one egg custard bun.  Mmmmmmm.  On another mission, I left with twelve steamed pork dumplings and they lasted me a couple of days.

I've found my new place of dim sum when I am not willing to wait in line at Good Luck Dim Sum.  Not to mention, this cafe has a larger variety and at least I don't have to circle what I want on a piece of paper.  I'm leaving that for the tourists.
author: Miika M.

description:
Man, this place should have more than 3 and a half stars! 

Go to place for dim sum if Good Luck is crowded...actually scratch that. GO to place for chow mein...a HUGE box for $3? Or a small box for $2? I can't remember, they changed their prices, but it's a REALLY good deal for decent, veggie chow mein. Also, my brother SWEARS by their har gow. IT IS BETTER than Good Luck's!! 

The line is never very long, and you get your dim sum and you can be on your merry way and gtfo of Clement st and HOME to actually EAT your delicious dim sum! :)
author: Alison N.

description: It's an on & off kinda place. They run out of their popular items after 2pm. Its cheap & simple but recently I had an order of Siu Mai & it was extremely salty, which lead me to take a whiff of the meat. There was an unfreshness smell to it which explains the extra salt. I didn't get sick or anything but I'm sure my blood pressure shot up. I hope they read this review b/c read it as constructive criticism.I want u to improve your business & customer can tell. It only happened just once & our family have gone here for dim sum for years along w/ the other shops on clement. They all have their fav. I will go back for other goodies.
author: M L.

description: This hole in the wall is pretty darn good. I came here because the dim sum place across the street had a 30 minute wait. Everything is inexpensive here! I came here the day before Chinese New Year eve and they ran out of all goods at 1 PM (Saturday). I had to wait 5 minutes for the freshly made steamed items to arrive. It only took 5 minutes. I did chow down on the last baked pork bun. That was the only thing sitting out. Btw, they only make the baked BBQ pork buns once per day so get em early before they're gone. I ended up with 3 pieces of steamed scallop in rice paper, 3 pieces of shrimp haw gao, 3 pieces of pork siu mai, and one bbq pork bun. All that for about $5.
author: Sandra L.

description: It was raining and my friends and I were visiting SF. We had a craving for some dim sum. Unfortunately, the original place we wanted to try near Clement street had no indoor seating area so we went inside Gourmet Dim Sum and Cafe, plus it said "gourmet" which means it has to be good, right? Uh let's just say that it cost $1.50 for 3 pieces and the best thing about this place was only the price. I ordered #2 deep fried meat dumpling and #31 beef rice noodle. The dumpling was big, but it lacked a good portion of meat. The beef rice noodle was ok, but I have tasted better. I left this place feeling full, but my craving for SF dim sum was not yet fulfilled. The service and the eating area were both a-ok, but overall I gave this place 2 stars for the food and lack of cleanliness. The next time you see "Gourmet," take a second look, it might just be a fancy title, but not a fancy place.
author: Zeela D.

description:
I remember when Gourmet first opened a couple of years ago, replacing a small Chinese market I believe.  Gourmet doesn't have quite as much variety as the other takeout dim sum places.  They're particularly skimpy in the buns department.  And the red bean department.  The price is comparable to other Chinese takeout places in this part of town.

Dumplings are 3 for $1.50 and the menu is in English (and Chinese).  I wanted the fresh shrimp rice noodle but they didn't have any (yet) so I ordered the following:
* Har gow: Tender, diced shrimp, minced bamboo shoots, fairly large, tasty
* Pork & preserved egg porridge ($2): Thick and pasty (pasty isn't a good thing in my book), nicer flavor than most takeout dim sum places (Good Luck still has the best porridge), not much preserved egg or meat, no scallions, no ginger.  
* Shark's fin dumpling: Mostly fatty ground pork, firm, with some carrots, pretty good

Everything was served nice and hot.  You can take it to go or grab a table there to eat it.  It's a no frills place and there's rarely a line.  Cash only of course.
author: Lolia S.

description:
Mexicans have menudo for their hangover cures.  Vietnamese offers you a bowl of pho for that nagging cold.  Matzo ball soup is the jewish penicillin.    

Well I have the perfect chinese remedy that takes care of all three above.  Me personally when I'm a little under the weather why not a delicious and cheap bowl of congee with pork and preserved egg (AKA 1K year old egg).  Best cure medicine for 2 buckaroos....and it's thick and hearty and it hits the spot.
author: David C.

description: This is going to be my new Saturday early morning ritual--get fresh, steamy dim sum for breakfast, then go grocery shopping. I loved everything here, definitely including the prices! The shumai were enormous! Mm mm. I kind of want to go back right now.
author: Vero K.

description:
I was heading to Good Luck Dim Sum but they were closed (Tues)! *devastated* I didn't know of any places that I wanted to go to for Har Gow. I was heading back to the parking lot with my boyfriend when Gourmet Dim Sum and Cafe caught my eyes. "Let's go there," I said. 

"Have you been there before?" My boyfriend asked.

"Nope, but let's try it out since I don't know where else I can find good Har Gow."

There was a line with 4 people when I walked in. The place was similar to Good Luck but smaller. We waited in line and ordered "2 Har Gow, 1 Siu Mai, 1 Steamed BBQ Pork Bun, 1 Steamed Chicken Bun, 1 Small Chow Mein, and 1 Chive Dumpling." Not knowing that this place would sell you one "piece" of dim sum and not just by orders, I only ended up with a little tray of dim sum, a little tray of noodle, and 2 steamed buns. The people behind me must have thought I was weird... :(

The dumplings were really plump. I took a bite of the Har Gow. It was sweet and juicy with just the right amount of bamboo shoot. I'd say it was comparable to Good Luck's BUT it's probably a tad bigger and a lot more oily. The chive dumpling was equally as delicious! I quickly went back in line to order more and this time I made sure I didn't order just one or two pieces. =P

All their dumplings were really oily...probably to prevent them from sticking together. They were very good dumplings so I didn't mind soaking up the extra oil with my napkin. My boyfriend finished his BBQ Pork Bun before I even had a chance to see it...so I don't know how it compares to Good Luck's. We finished almost everything except 2 pieces of siu mai and 2 pieces of har gow, which I took home with me. We were stuffed and everything was just barely over $10! What a deal?!

Gourmet have a larger selection of dim sum than Good Luck. They have a variety of rice rolls (e.g. fresh shrimp, dried baby shrimp, beef) and several more items that Good Luck doesn't carry. They have Wonton Noodle Soup for $3! The translation on their menu says "Wonton Soup" but it's actually has noodle too. A lot of people ordered that and that thing is NOT puny. It's what you would typically pay $6 or more at typical restaurants. Their wontons were a good size. 

There's only 2 bottle of soy sauce and 1 bottle of hot sauce, so you have to share with other people and you might have to hop over to another table to borrow their sauce. The customers there were really nice and everybody seemed very comfortable with sharing. :)

Best of all, the lady called me "lang lui" =D That's pretty common actually. I promise that's not the reason I'm giving them 4 stars. I'd be very happy if either Gourmet or Good Luck would move to Portland.
author: Jennifer L.

description:
Since Good Luck Dim Sum has closed for renovation, I came here.  I was surprised at the difference.  The shrimp dumplings were larger than the ones at Good Luck but overly salty.  The texture was nice, very tender.  The best dumplings were the Chive dumplings since they were very tasty, tender, and a decent size.  The sesame ball was huge but had nothing but air in it,  the usual ball of sweet black bean paste was replaced by a smidgen and seemed like just an after thought. Extremely disappointing. 

They were out of almost everything else on a Friday at 2:00PM.  No sticky rice, no beef fun, and the chow mein looked dry and unappetizing.  The service was really lacking.  The lady wasn't outright rude but seemed like she didn't want to serve me and basically ignored me.  I had to ask for things several times before she answered me and then she would hesitate as if she was considering whether or not to answer me.  She also calculated the wrong tab for me and at the last minute noticed the drink in my hand so we had to pay her twice.  I'm not sure if I would come back.  Probably not.
author: Lorissa W.

description:
Clement is not the place for good dim sum at all! I still would rather get it from Chinatown, but for those lazy weekend mornings when we want quick dim sum, we'll come here. I don't think I would have stumbled across this place just because the outside isn't very inviting. Its dim inside and the owners should probably do something about that, maybe they would get more business? 

Anyhow, I came here when Clement Restaurant sold me cold dim sum, and this place was on the same block. The ha gow is good here but I didn't like that oil almost dripped off the ha gow I bought today. Ew. 

This is one of the few places on Clement that still sells dim sum for 3/$1.50.
author: Connie C.

description:
When I lived in SF, and craved cheap dim sum, this is where I went. Very cheap and very tasty.

They're still very cheap. Tasty? Well, the shumai was good. The har gow would've been better if I didn't crunch into shrimp shells. Chow mein was so bland that I topped it with sriracha... and I NEVER eat sriracha.

I'll need to try the other places next time.
author: Julia G.

description:
When I'm low on cash and and want some quick and inexpensive food, here are the food items I get as a vegetarian:

lunch:
-small noodles for $2.00 (they really hook you up and fill up the container to the max!)
-egg rolls ( I think they're fitty cents)

desert:
-sesame ball with sweet red bean paste (again I think it's fitty cents)
-sugar cake-it's so cheap I can't even remember the cost!

Advice: older Chinese ladies will cut in line. Speak up and TELL the CASHIER YOU were first in line.
author: Lucky P.

description: Cheap __ good quality dim sum! I'm used to spending about $15 a person for good sit-down dim sum where old Chinese ladies wheel around a cart and try to upsell you like you're buying a SUV without leather seats and a sound system. But on Clement and the Inner Richmond in SF, this is one of the multiple dim sum spots that has a good selection of quality dim sum for dirt cheap (think $1.20 per order). I get the usual mix of dumplings, shrimp and rice flour specials, etc. The food is a bit cold though, so take it home, enjoy in your PJ's and microwave it first.
author: Chuck N.

description: TRY THEIR WONTON SOUP. BEST IN ALL THE ASIAN LAND IN SF. and then try everything else on the menu! :-P
author: Jen M.

description:
A very good and very cheap dim sum place, wildly underrated on yelp. I 've tried everything accept for the buns (I usually get those at another pastry shop a few doors down).  The sufferings are usually fresh and lively, and the oils are less intrusive.   Best of all, unlike many of the other dim sum places in this area, the wraps are thinner, allowing the flavor of the stuffing to come through.  

As is often the case with yelp, I scratch my head at the ratings. 4 stars if compared to Hong Kong and favs in other regions, five if compared to the other places around here.
author: Pan K.

description:
This place definitely has fresh dim sum.  I always judge the freshness and quality of a dim sum place by its hargow (shrimp dumpling).  It's always fresh without the stale seafood smell/taste.  

Lady who works there is very honest.  If something is cold, she'll let me know.  If I ask her to heat it up and she thinks it'll ruin the texture of the dim sum, she'll tell me that also.

Their jook (congee) is thick and tasty.  Their spare ribs rice dish has a simple cabbage side dish and it shows how simple and non-greasy their food is.  I definitely pick this dim sum to go place over other ones on Clement St.
author: Yvonne Y.

description:
My favorite Chinese bakeries are usually so crowded that I get anxious trying to figure-out what unusual baked, fried or steamed blobjects to select.  How refreshing, then, that this place was completely empty when I decided to try it. I ordered a selection of items to go.

Unfortunately, everything I ordered was cold. This surely blunted the food's flavor and gummed-up itstextures, too. If I was inclined to return to this place again, I'd plan to reheat everything at home before eating.

The baked pork bun (my reference standard for judging dim sum) was basically good, even cold. It had very average dough, but without the nice honey glaze that some places add, yet the filling was tasty enough.

Potstickers were just ho-hum. Bland and unremarkable. 

I also ordered a piece of turnip cake, just to try something new. What I got was a shiny, quivering white mass that provided neither the joy of true cake nor the robust flavor of turnips. Instead, it had an insipid taste and a lumpy, greasy texture that I found somewhat revolting. Maybe that was the finest turnip cake in all the land, but I doubt I'll order it anywhere else to compare.

Looking back, I think I'll stick with those bakeries that are packed wall-to-wall with patrons.
author: Todd H.

description: i love dim sum.  I love good and cheap dim sum.  This place had ok dim sum and it was cheap so one out of two ain't bad.  I was taking my inlaws to the drs and I got so hungry I had to go hunt me down some grub.  Low and behold, this place popped up and I decided to give it a try.  This is not a dine in place, it is take dim sum.  I was hungry and it seemed good at the time, but after my hubby had some, he was it was just ok, not as good as Delicious Dim Sum in Chinatown.  But hey, we didn't have to go all the way to chinatown at least.  I may be back if I get stuck in a bind and am craving dim sum, but I might want to try some other places on Clement first.
author: Jacki C.

description: This is my go-to for jook because they usually offer chicken and the pork and preserved egg one and have always been kind to me. My mom also loves the white rice triangles from here. The shrimp and chive dumplings are decent, but I prefer them at Good Luck.
author: Krystle S.

description: If you are looking for the best to-go dim sum, this is the place in the Richmond district. The shrimp dumplings are better than Good Luck Dim Sum because the skin is thinner, and the chef knows how to make the skin wrapped tightly around the shrimp once the dumpling is steamed. Also, the scallop dumplings (there is no scallop inside; the dumplings are shaped like scallops) are fantastic.
author: GR Z.

description: BBQ pork buns almost as good as in Hong Kong. Solid place rivals Clement Dim Sum. For the price of a burrito in Los altos you can feed a whole software team. Long lines, no credit cards. Otherwise pretty good.
author: Zarko D.

description:
My friend and I randomly stopped in here at lunch last Sunday.  I'm not very experienced with dim sum, and I've never done it in a 'take out' manner so it was kind of confusing.  But the few items that I did want, like egg tarts, spare ribs, and shu mai, they had, so that was fine with me.  There was definetly a language barrier in ordering though, which made things I think confusing for both myself and the woman working the counter.  I think the thing is either bring someone who knows what they're doing, or else go at a time its not busy so you aren't rushed to decided what you want.  
It was definetly cheap; my friend and I ate for $8.  Just don't expect anything fancy.
author: Jim G.

description:
I love pork buns. This pork bun was very flavourful. And since gays might be able to marry soon, this also means we can marry whatever we want right? Like our animals. Like maybe my pet parrot. Or my cat Baby Jesus. No but really, I think I will marry this pork bun. And when it pisses me off, I can just eat it. No alimony for you pork bun.

The pot stickers were a bit cold by the time we ate them (she reheated them in the microwave) and which was only like 5 minutes. I  wanted soy sauce but...sigh. 

I loves the pork bun. I will be back. Pot sticker, I think it was a brief affair.
But definitely not marriage material..

($14.50 for four people, hollaaaah)
author: Lauren S.

description:
I mean, it's not Yank Sing or anything, but it takes the edge off.  I don't go for any of the meats - there's just something I can't quite fix in my head to fit around the concept of a ball of meat with skin on it, steamed to death in a metal strainer.  Call me crazy.

However, I venture for the shrimp dumpling, scallop dumpling, and shrimp and cilantro every time.  3 each, 9 total, 3 bucks or something ridiculously cheap. 

Then I head over to New May Wah, grab a bag of bok choy hearts for a dollar nineteen, and dinner is served.
author: Tamar D.

description: Went here the other day for some pork buns. The lady working wasn't very friendly and the pork buns were okay...
author: Mertani G.

description: Their shrimp dumplings are better than Good Luck Dim Sum.  That's saying a lot.  Also had the scallop dumplings and they were awesome too.  Would come here over GLDS any day due to the wait and quality of the seafood dumplings.
author: Wilson B.

description:
this hole in the take out  restaurant has cheap dim sum, (3 for 1.50) pork buns (.75) chow mein (1.50-2.50) and other fast food ready to eat items.

sampled the 
-pork siu mai(3/1/50) attractvely  large, dry and juiced., some gristle some msg. similar to  what most dim sum sit down restaurant offer.
-chicken bun (.50) large fluffy exterior, small dry chicken filling. the bun's texture is no. 1. filling is  average.

friendly service, upselling possible here.

should i score an expensive parking space,  gourmet is a viable option.
author: Victor G.

description:
best steamed shrimp and chive dumpling hands down.

i live closer to Chinatown than Richmond, but I'd rather go out of my way 20 minutes for the awesome dim sum.
author: Samantha W.

description:
Oh my gawd!  How can it be that NO ONE has Yelped Gourmet Dimsum yet?  Funny thing is, it never occurred to me to do so before today either.... *hmmph*

Gourmet Dimsum is a pretty small shop near the corner of 8th Avenue and Clement Street; I discovered it a few years ago when Good Luck Dimsum was closed.  It was a miserable, gray morning on which the sky seemed to be spitting maliciously at me just to further bum me out.  I trolled around Clement Street to find a suitable substitute for Good Luck and, to my surprise, what started out as a major disappointment exposed me to even greater culinary treasures.

If you're a fan of steamed shrimp & ginger dumplings, shrimp & chive dumplings, shrimp & cilantro dumplings and scallop dumplings, you'll never be disappointed if you get them from Gourmet Dimsum.  

Why not?  Because my friends, they serve it up big, plump and hot.  Don't we all like it like that? *wink*

Each tasty dumpling has an impressive bulge, and I would estimate they are sized about one and a half to two times the size of most that I've seen elsewhere.  Don't fret, though.  This increase in dumpling size doesn't mean they cheap out on you and fatten the dumpling by wrapping the innards with thick skin.  The skin here is thin, chewy and translucent like it's supposed to be.  

What else impressed me about Gourmet Dimsum is that they wrap their rice skin around dumpling guts that are clean-tasting (you know what I'm talking about ... no mystery meat in it or strange aftertaste), freshly steamed (always hot), and packed with the freshest (bright green cilantro and chives) and highest quality (firm, clean and translucent shrimp) ingredients.

Next time you're invited to a potluck brunch, stop by Gourmet Dimsum and get a big carton of dumplings.  It's the only package of "big, plump and hot" that you can share with your friends that is guaranteed to elicit cries of "wow!" and "delicious!!!" from the whole crowd... ;P
author: Jenny K.

description:
Being across the street from the best dim sum in the city (Good Luck Dim Sum) must be like Ashlee Simpson sitting in Jessica Simpson's shadows. This place rocks but how the hell can you compete with the best around? This place has the siu mai, buns and dumplings you expect everywhere for a low price. It's solid but the main dim sum pieces are second shelf next to Good Luck. 

This place does have more desserts, friendlier staff and much better seating options than Good Luck. You can actually get a table here that doesn't have 3 days of crust on the surface. They rarely has a long line so it's quick here. 

For first timers heed my word of advice and bring a pen. It's confusing to order dim sum and even harder when you're on the spot and 3 people are waiting for you to figure out your order. So do yourself a favor and grab a menu off the counter and write down what you want before you make a fool out of yourself. Trust me.. it's better than figuring out the difference between siu mai versus hai gow. 

I go here if Good Luck has a long line (which often it does) and on Monday when Good Luck is closed. This place really good.. but probably be great if it wasn't next to my favorite restaurant in the city.
author: Dan T.

description: Always long line but worth it. Best deal in the city. I like there bean, egg yoke and lotus bun. Their pork and beef shuimi are the best and moist.
author: Dee B.

description:
O.K. so I like to eat & eat I did on Saturday. I've been jonesin' for the scallop dumplings @ this place ever since Ray Y. introduced me to Gourmet Dim Sum. What a dive but what awesome dim sum! Fresh & they definitely don't skimp on the ingredients. I ordered 3 orders of the scallop & 2 of the har gow & almost ate the whole thing!

The only drawback - it's a bitch to find parking! (weekdays may be a bit easier) It was worth the 5x circling for parking though.
author: Darlene D.

description:
Visited today for the first time.  Found things to LOVE (bbq pork bun for 80c, please!) and some were a little strange (Yankee taste buds here).  the fillings seemed good quality, and they were patient enough with us ordering based on looking and supplying extra forks and sauce.  I'll be back but I'll have to start building a repertoire of things I like rather than ordering haphazardly.  Haven't tried the desserts but they looked lovely.

Also, 3 veggie egg rolls (spring rolls) for 1.50!  They're as good as any spring rolls I've tasted and so cheap!  I could get full here for $3 easily.
author: Lauren J.

description:
A friend took me to the Clement Street mini-Chinatown two years ago, well before I became a San Fran denizen. Since our move in July 2007, my girlfriend and I have preferred to stay (and eat) closer to home, i.e. Potrero Hill. And you can't blame us, for with the wonderful weather and 'scene' in PH, Mission and Castro, we are bound by an invisible thread (fuzzy shackles) to those parts of town. 

But after we spent a day in GG Park rowing, not unlike Olympic contenders and sniffing and eyeballing plants in the Conservatory, we were ravenous.  It was time to board the Clement Street promenade for dim sum or SNACK TIME! My gf nixed a few places that seemed too pork-infested, grimy or smelled like 100-times refried soybean oil. We weren't going to settle for less than the pros...

This place offered an entertaining frequenter who let us in on a little secret: the shrimp and shrimp-cilantro dim sum had the thinnest wrap on the block(s). The owner seemed dedicated to us having a yummy time by bringing a special sauce over to our table. We didn't try the egg custard bun, but I am not the fondest of this concept to begin with. However, as an avid meat-eater I took my taste of the BBQ pork bun and- great! -- No weird sinews in the meat, plus a fluffy lightly sweet rice dough, with no traceable oil! 

After coming home and reading Yelp reviews for this place, my adventurous palate squealed for some congee, hang over or not, even if its to involve a thrice rotten egg! Will go back after the next SF urban adventure in Golden Gate Park.
author: Masha R.

description: OMG! The lady microwaved our dim sum right in front of us.  Eecchh!
author: Ahope H.

description:
what i ordered... har gow(shrimp dumpling), scallops dumpling, pork shumai and steamed bbq pork bun

i've been here a lot of times before for their dumplings and it never dissapoints me. scallops and shrimp dumplings were great... perfect dough, good size, lots of well seasoned fillings and soooo inexpensive. pork shumai was good too. so five star for these three.!

steamed pork bun was an absolute contrast, i've never had one before at this place and it will be my last to try as well. it was the worst i've had, bun was ok the split top type but the fillings were just plain yucky... not even sweet, tasteless semi red colored starchy sauce with pieces of something like boiled pork. so zero star for this one!

good for take-out only, drive to the nearby golden gate park to enjoy your semi loot or go get yourself a cup of coffee at that nice american bakery/cafe up a block or two.

ambiance... so-so
service... ok(lady was all smile)
cost... $-
author: Gors P.

description: For me steam table Dim Sum is very hit and miss and to be honest for me this spot is about the values plus the woman at the counter who has always been friendly and nice. I do not order many things here but they have a variety of Steamed Buns filled with meat with my favorite being the Steamed Pork Bun which are a great value at 3 for $1.50, they have a tasty filling and have always been fresh. The only other option I have explored here is the Large Chow Mein for just $2.50, this is boxed in a large lunch size container crammed full of Noodles. Lots of other stuff on the menu with most being 3 for $1.50, and easy seating if you want to mix with the locals.
author: Joseph A.

description:
Well these guys dim sums are so so. They are like 99 ranch dimsum.  the wraps are thick, and there is often not much substance with in it.

Saying that, you have to look at in perspective that the food here is very cheap and tasty. The lady behind the counter though seem only to speak cantonese was very hepful and patient. 

I would recommend order all you want together and have her warm it up up for you. It will taste so much better after that ... ~smile.
author: Amlan S.

description: Mediocre at best.  It doesn't really try to distinguish itself from the rest of the dim sum places in the same block.  Probably not going back to this place again.
author: Lawrence C.

description:
In the middle of a long bike ride on a cold day, we suddenly got really hungry as we got closer to Clement street.  We tried to go to Good Luck Dim Sum but the line was too long and there were no tables. So we decided to just duck into the next Dim Sum place we saw.
Meh. 
The place is a dive but that is ok.
We ordered a tray full of food for the both of us for just $8.  Cheap!  But I get nervous when food is too cheap, so for me that is really not much of plus. 
The little shrimp thingys and the little scallop thingys were tasty, the little pork things were good but everything else was not so.  It would have been better and a three star review had everything not been cold.  We were already cold, and room temperature "steamed" dumplings did not hit the spot.
I wont be coming back here, there are too many choices on Clement.
author: Nilu r.

description:
Found some room in my belly following a feast of chicken buns at Good Luck Dim Sum.  So hopped down to Gourmet to check it out.  Gourmet is not the word I would use to describe GDS.  

Order up front, food has been prepared in advance and is quite cheap.  The beef rice noodes (I got the last one!) were pretty good but the rice in lotus leaf was subpar.  Both items were only $3 total, which was a deal.

Language barrier was difficult too - when I first asked for beef with rice noodle, she went for the chow mein and I had to order by the number on the menu to get my intentions across.

I'm a sucker for the beef rice noodles and this did the trick, otherwise save your ducats and squander them on buns at Good Luck.  

Packaged to go.  Not an environment that encourages lingering over a meal.  Not that my food would last that long....
author: Aaron T.

description:
Cheap is always good in my dictionary...and decent is also a good word. Both describes the dim sum offered at Gourmet. I like their pork buns and pot stickers..but on the whole there are other dim sum places that fill me up. The plus of this place is that they offer pictures on some of their items from their menu listings, and the servers are always nice to explain what items they have.

The back seating areas are clean and not blocking anyone's path.  Try out their rice porridge...and their chow mein is really nice as well.
author: Pauline L.

description:
You can't go to San Francisco without getting Dim Sum at sum point. At first my brother and I were going to go to Burger King to appease his daughter. I was secretly hoping we weren't as I'm on a Test of Wills of not eating burgers. To my luck, we couldn't find parking at the BK on Geary and ended up on Clement. We saw a couple of Dim Sum places and decided to have that instead. Plus there was a readily available parking space. Yipeee! The first one we went to (don't recall the name) was closed on Tuesdays. So, we ended up at Gourmet because it was a little under a block away, so we tried it. 
I'm sure there's much better Dim Sum places, but I think any Dim Sum place in SF Trumps most places in So Cal.
 Prices were incredibly reasonable. We ordered the standard stuff. Some Baos, Har Gow, Shu Mai and Pot Stickers. The Baos were good as were the Shu Mai. The Har Gow was average and the Pot Stickers... I could have done without. Everything got cold really fast after we ordered. Strange. I know it's SF, but it wasn't that cold a day. 
Service wasn't the fastest, but it gave me time to find the Engrish on the menu board. I found two mistakes. 
Not the best Dim Sum I have had in SF, but sure beats the heck out of Burger King!
author: H Q.

description:
Go for the Char Siu Bao - stay for the no nonsense counter ladies. 

Great bao. Fluffy, moist, and most importantly, chock full of yummy porky goodness. Where other places skimp on the char siu and over do it on the bao; Gourmet Dim Sum has struck it's perfect balance.

The bean paste bao is awesome too.
author: Bunny H.

description: After sampling a couple items here, I prefer Clement Restaurant that's nearer 7th Avenue on the same block. Their white honeycomb cake (bak tong gou) is surprisingly decent: it has a great, light texture from having airy holes so that when you bite into a piece, it doesn't have a chewy, mochi-like consistency. But their fried crescent dumpling (ham siu kok) was unimpressive, having a horribly greasy, non-crispy and bland dough.
author: Cliff W.

description:
Just to level-set, this is take-out.
So my 4 stars means not that it was really good on the overall scale of restaurants, but that it's really good for what it is: take-out, fast-food, Chinese.

There are many places like this one on Clement St. in San Francisco that have a take-out counter with Dim Sum-type dumplings. I've tried 4-5 of them. This one is the best of the lot.

All of the dumpling take-out places on Clement St. charge about the same price - give or take a few cents.

I tried the Har Gow and the Hong Sai Gow (like a Har Gow plus chives, I think) and the dragon dumpling. All were very good for take-out, and as good as or better than most sit-down Chinese places I've been to.

The shrimp didn't taste old or overcooked.

Despite what some of the other reviewers said, I found the woman who worked the counter to be nice. She even answered a couple questions about ingredients for me.

Downside: they didn't have any deep-fried stuff. For that, you have to go down another half block or so to Clement Restaurant. (I have a review for that place, too.)
author: Gregg K.

description:
I happed upon this place while coming back from GG park with my gf...

can't believe it was so cheap!! and the quality is awesome!  even better than many Chinatown dim-sum places...

the shrimp-celantro dim-sum was my favorite, and if you order the small chow mein, you'll get a huge mountain!

Egg rolls and other shrimp dum-sums were also great...

all-in-all, perfect if you want a quick, cheap and quality dim-sum meal...the guy is cool too!
author: Rollio R.

description: this place is cheap! meatless chow mein, small $1.50, large which is HUGE, is only $2.50.   i got two larges.  nom nom nom
author: Pickle R.

description: I only went in there to get a BBQ Pork Steamed Bun, but I also got their Chow Mein.  It was pretty damn good. Go get that Chow Mein, people.
author: Allison R.

description: I like this place. The Har Gow and Sui Mi are definitely better than most on clement. Hands down - I think I've tried damn near every other place too! Their steamed pork buns are pretty good too.
author: Mark G.

description: this is the best dim sum in bay area real taste of shrimp and fresh and super cheap one order of shrimp is 1.50 per order has three pieces i go there every week
author: Jinny S.

description:
Good general Dim Sum and attentive staff, although we were there for a good meal after a race. They only had about 12 different types of Dim sum and didn't' return to the table side unless asked specifically for some attention.

Any cold food was quickly taken away and reheated for you before serving it
author: C Y.

description: this place is amazing!!!  cheap delicious dim sum served fresh and steaming. its a cafe style eatery, the staff speak little english, but are very helpful.  i went out for brunch / breakfast and managed to feed me and 3 others for 15$ total
author: michael d.

description: It was the only place open compared to all the other dim sum places around the area.  3 for $1.50 for the shumai and the hakaw..not bad.  I still prefer china town, but dim sum here is comparable.
author: Abby E.

description: I love their buns: egg yolk, flower, lotus, bbq pork, bbq chicken you name it! great little treats for bus rides home or just blustery afternoons.
author: Frances g.

description: There is nothing gourmet about this place.  I got sick twice eating here about three years ago and have never gone back since.  I suppose I was too foolish at that time to make the connection the first time, but after the second time, my Foodbeard said, "Darling, it's that dim sum that's making you sick."  I had to concur.
author: Rose Q.

description:
Cheap, divey, but decent. I'm not used to ordering dim sum at a counter, so there was some pressure in deciding what I wanted and delivering my order loudly and promptly. You don't come here for four star service, so you just have to be one mental step ahead of the lady behind the counter, I suppose. 

On to the food. Their chicken congee didn't come with a thousand year old egg, but the portion was generous and flavorful with ginger and succulent shreds of chicken. The fried savory rice dough ball (for lack of a better description) was crispy and chewy, but sadly, cold and seriously lacking on filling. Har gow was sticky and succulent, but the Chinese chive and shrimp dumpling was the best of them all. I'm not a huge fan of egg custard tarts, but theirs wasn't bad-- the crust was actually flaky and crisp, not the soft, limp deal that usually houses the custard filling. Finally, the char sui bao. To me, a dim sum restaurant's overall quality is based on their char sui bao. This place didn't quite pass the test: the pork wasn't sweet enough, had a faint hint of cooking wine, and was pretty fatty. Sorry Gourmet Dim Sum. I could come back, but when there's a ton of other cheap places to try on Clement, it might be a while.
author: Tammy C.

description: Don't let this place deceive you.   Their food is quite decent and will not disappoint you.  The girl behind the counter was quite polite.
author: liliana l.

description: i was on a congee quest and decided to walk into gourmet dimsum for a container of soupy rice, thousand egged, porky goodness. i left with a few other additional things at a grand total of $4 measly dollars. the congee was only $2 for a big container. granted i've had better but it was definitely worth double what they were charging. and oh-so-satisfying. the other notable items: airy and delightfully crispy sesame balls. yes! and turnip cakes that were still delectable even after a day. (but then again, anything you reheat by frying even after a day would probably still be delicious- ha!).
author: ray e.
